title: Questor share tip: Don't catch this Glencore falling knife
text:
GX8.AS 0.00 
Investor (Stockholm: INVE-A.ST - news ) 's are running out of patience with FTSE 100 listed miner as commodity prices tumble, says Questor 
Glencore (Amsterdam: GX8.AS - news ) 131.8p +8.65p Questor says SELL 
Glencore [LON:GLEN] is planning to carry out drastic surgery on its balance sheet to reduce debt levels and protect its credit rating, but with the outlook for commodity prices still far from certain Questor wouldn’t go anywhere near this falling-knife share. 
The FTSE 100-listed mining giant amassed too much debt during the good times to fund a voracious acquisition strategy, and it has now been forced to take emergency measures to prevent a credit downgrade that would have fatally wounded its trading operations. 
The plan to cut the dividend, issue equity, close mining operations and sell assets gives it some much-needed breathing space, but the fundamental problems for shareholders in this company remains. Glencore’s profits are falling sharply, it no longer pays a dividend, and the value of the mines it owns are falling as commodity prices tumble because the world’s biggest buyer, China, is slowing down. 
The holders of debt in this company will be more secure following the actions, but those holding equity are looking increasingly at risk. 
Glencore’s most recent results to the end of June show a debt pile of $47.3bn (£30.9bn), or $29.6bn excluding debt used to fund trading, against shareholder’s equity of $45bn. So, in the unlikely event it had to repay all its debts tomorrow, shareholders could get nothing. 
The refinancing plan will take time to execute and involves plenty of risk. 
Many questions remain, not least at what price is the $2.5bn equity raise to be held and how dilutive will it be? The suspension of the mines will cut costs but also hit full-year revenue and profits. The group is now a forced seller of assets in a depressed market. 
Questor advised shareholders to sell in January of this year at 244.2p and as the debt holders move closer to the driving seat in this situation we would avoid any temptation to go bargain hunting.
